choices.text: 45
55
65
75

questions.text: At what age do current guidelines for osteoporosis prevention recommend initiation of screening with this modality for women at average risk?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 65

  • The image shows a DEXA scan (Dual Energy XRay Absorptimetry) done for assessement of bone mineral density
  • BMD testing is recommended for all menopausal women who:
    1. > 65 years 
    2. ≥ risk factor for osteoporosis
    3. h/o fracture
  • Additionally, screening is considered or perimenopausal women if they have a specific risk factor such as prior low-trauma fracture, have a low BMI, or are taking a medication known to accelerate bone loss

Osteoporosis risk factors:

Educational Objective: 

  • BMD testing is recommended for all menopausal women who:
    1. > 65 years 
    2. ≥ risk factor for osteoporosis
    3. h/o fracture

Ref: Page 481, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Hypoechoic linear striations
Anechoic areas within the myometrium
Well-defined endometrial–myometrial junction
Asymmetrically thickened and heterogeneous myometrium

questions.text: Sonographic features of adenomyosis, include all EXCEPT which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Well-defined endometrial–myometrial junction

  • Investigation of choice for adenomyosis is ultrasound (TVS)
  • With TVS, findings of adenomyosis are:
  1. Anterior or posterior myometrial wall appearing thicker than its counterpart
  2. Myometrial texture heterogeneity
  3. Small myometrial hypoechoic cysts, which are cystic glands within ectopic endometrial foci
  4. Striated projections extending from the endometrium into the myometrium
  5. Ill-defined endo-myometrial junction
  6. Globally enlarged uterus

Educational Objective: 

  • Adenomyosis is best diagnosed by ultraound (TVS)

Ref: Page 214, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: b,c,d,e
a,b,c,d,f
c,d,f
b,c,d,f

questions.text:
Uses of sonography in the evaluation and treatment of infertility include which of the following?

a. Anti-sperm antibodies

b. Monitoring of folliculogenesis in normal and stimulated cycles

c. Demonstration and characterization of congenital uterine anomalies

d. Ovarian reserve

e. Tubal spasm

f. Endometrial cavity evaluation
questions.solution:
Ans: D.  b,c,d,f

  • Sonography (especially trans vaginal sonography - TVS) is helpful in the evaluation of infertility. 
  • It is useful in
    • Endometrial evaluation
    • Ovarian follicle study in both normal and induced cycles
    • Congenital uterine anomalies can be seen through a better study for these is a 3D USG or an MRI (Ix of choice)
    • Ovarian reserve (antral follicle count)

Other Options: 

  • Anti- sperm antibodies are tested by either Mixed Antiglobulin Reaction (MAR) test or the Immunobead Test (IBT) 
  • Tubal pathology/ patency is best determined by a laparoscopic chromotubation or a hysterosalpingography (HSG)

Educational Objective

In Evaluation of Infertility, the initial investigations of choice include

  • For male factor: Semen analysis
  • For ovarian factor: History/ Follicular imaging/ serum progesterone level on Day 21
  • For tubal factor: HSG
  • For uterine factor: Trans-vaginal sonography

Ref: Page 31, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Pregnancy
History of PID
Iodine allergy
Acute pelvic infection

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a contraindication to doing an HSG?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. History of PID

HSG

  • An HSG (Hysterosalpingogram) is typically used for evaluation of female infertility. 
  • It helps assess
    • The endocervical canal
    • The endometrial cavity
    • The fallopian tube lumina by injecting radiopaque contrast material through the cervical canal and seeing their patency
  • HSG is used as an initial evaluation of tubal patency.
  • HSG is performed between cycle days 5 and 10 of the menstrual cycle
  • A Leech Wilkinson cannula is introduced just beyond the internal os. The dye is injected through this. 
  • Contraindications to HSG are acute pelvic infection, active uterine bleeding, pregnancy, and iodine allergy.
  • A history of PID is not a contra-indication to PID

Educational Objective: 

A Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an investigation used in initial evaluation of tubal patency in infertile women. It also helps assess the uterine cavity and Mullerian anomalies. 

Ref: Page 39, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Diagnosis of adenomyosis
Initial evaluation of suspected gynecologic disease
Detailed characterization of congenital mullerian anomalies
Evaluation of endometrial lesions when sonography is nondiagnostic in a patient who is a poor surgical candidate

questions.text: Uses of magnetic resonance (MR) imaging in gynecology include all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Initial evaluation of suspected gynecologic disease

  • Although sonography is widely used in suspected gynecologic disease, MR imaging may add information when sonographic findings are equivocal.
  • Specifically, its multiplanar imaging, superior soft-tissue contrast, and large field of view are advantages.
  • Common indications or MR imaging include:
    • Distorted pelvic anatomy
    • Large masses that are poorly delineated with sonography
    • Indeterminate cases of adenomyosis
    • An endometrial disorder in poor surgical candidates.
    • Evaluation and subsequent surveillance o pelvic malignancies
    • Mullerian anomalies

Educational Objective: 

  • In Gynecological pathology, an ultraosund is usually the prliminary imaging modality
  • An MRI however gives additional information especially in distorted pelvic anatomy, endometriosis, large masses, suspected malignancies and Mullerian anomalies

Ref: Page 42, Williams Gyn 3rd edition

choices.text: Septate uterus
Arcuate uterus
Uterus didelphys
Unicornuate uterus

questions.text: Of Mullerian defects, which has the lowest associated risk of recurrent miscarriage and is shown here in this three-dimensional sonographic image?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Arcuate uterus

  • Arcuate uterus is not associated with poor obstetrical outcome

Other Options

  • Option A: Septate uterus and unicornuate uterus is associated with infertility, increased abortions, preterm labor, malpresentations and FGR
  • Option C: Uterine didelphys also has a better obstetric outcome although it is associated with abortions, preterm labor, FGR and rarely malpresentations
  • Option D: Bicornuate uterus is also associated with mid trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations

Educational Objective: 

  • Best reproductive performance amongst Mullerian anomalies: Arcuate uterus (f/b uterine didelphys)
  • Poorest reprodutive performance: Septate uterus and Unicornuate uterus

Ref: Page 42, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Less patient discomfort
Superior detection of intracavitary masses
Ability to perform at any time of the cycle
Simultaneous assessment of myometrium and endometrium

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of saline infusion sonography compared with transvaginal sonography?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Superior detection of intracavitary masses

  • A saline infusion sonography (SIS) is superior to a TVS for visualization of the endometrial cavity and in delineating submucosal fibroids and endometrial polyps

Other Options:

  • Option A: Less patient disconfort: Both SIS and HSG cause a slight discomfort and pain to the patient and anti-spasmodics are usually given prior to the procedure
  • Option C: Ability to perform at any time of the cycle: Both an SIS and HSG are done between Day 7-10 of the menstrual cycle
  • Option D: Simultaneous assessment of myometrium and endometrium: The myometrium is not assessed in both SIS and HSG. 

Educational Objective: 

  • A saline infusion sonography (SIS) is superior to a TVS for visualization of the endometrial cavity and in delineating submucosal fibroids and endometrial polyps
  • An HSG is better than SIS for determining tubal patency

Ref: Page 42, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: The main diagnostic tool is a Pap smear
It is a rare cause of abnormal uterine bleeding
Infertility has been linked directly with this growth
Use of oral contraceptive pills appears to be protective

questions.text: Characteristics of the soft, fleshy intrauterine growth, shown here exhibiting a single feeder vessel, include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Use of oral contraceptive pills appears to be protective

  • The image shows an endometrial polyp
  • It can be diagnosed by
    • TVS
    • HSG
    • Saline infusion sonography (SIS)
    • Hysteroscopy
  • It is a common cause of AUB (menorrhagia, post-menopausal bleeding) and is associated with hyper-estrogenic states
  • Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in their growth
  • Patient risk factors include increasing age, obesity, and tamoxifen use
  • Use of oral contraceptive pills are protective. OCPs also protect against
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Ovarian cancer
    • Colo-rectal cancer
  • Infertility has been linked indirectly with endometrial polyps
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic polypectomy

 

Other Options:

  • Option A: The main diagnostic tool is a Pap smear: A pap semar is a screening test for cervical cancer
  • Option B: It is a rare cause of abnormal uterine bleeding: Endometrial polyps are common causes of AUB
  • Option C: Infertility has been linked directly with this growth: Endometrial polyps have been implicated in infertility but INDIRECTLY. 

Educational Objective: 

  • Oral contraceptive pills are protective for 
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Ovarian cancer
    • Colo-rectal cancer

Ref: Page 188, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Intramural
Subserosal
Submucosal type 0
Submucosal type I

questions.text: What type of leiomyoma is shown in this sonographic image?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Intramural

  • This is a TVS image showing a fibroid (Well circumscribed lesion)
  • It is seen in the myometrium, hence it is an intra-mural fibroid

Other Options

  • Option B: A subserous fibroid is one towards the serosal surface (outer surface of uterus)
  • Option C and D: A submucosal fibroid is a fibroid in the endometrial cavity
    • Type 0: Completely in the cavity (pedunculated submucosal)
    • Type 1: < 50% is intramural
    • Type 2: > 50% is intramural

Educational Objective: 

The image below shows the 3 main types of fibroids:

 

 

Ref: Page 206, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Combination oral contraceptives
Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist
Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNGIUS)

questions.text: A 44-year-old patient presents with complaints of menorrhagia which has been increasing. She has no other medical problems. 3D USG reveals the findings as shown below. All EXCEPT which of the following are choices for medical treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNGIUS)

  • The image shows a large submucosal fibroid
  • This can be managed medically by
    • NSAIDs
    • Antifibrinolytics
    • Combined OCPS
    • Injectable Progesterones (DMPA)
    • SPRMs (ulipristal, mifepristone)
    • GnRH agonists
    • LNG-IUS (Mirena)
  • However Mirena, is contra-indicated when there is significant distortion of the endometrial cavity which is seen in a submucosal fibroid; hence an LNG-IUS should not be given to this woman

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Combined OCPs: These will reduce the symotoms of the patient (menorrhagia)
  • Option B: Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA): This is an injectable progesterone and this acts by causing endometrial atrophy and hence reducing the bleeding
  • Option C: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist: This ireduces the size of the fibroid by 50% and is also effective in reducing symptoms of menorrhagia

Educational Objective: 

Mirena (LNG-IUS), is contra-indicated when there is significant distortion of the endometrial cavity which is seen in a submucosal fibroid; hence an LNG-IUS should not be given to this woman

Ref: 208, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Ovarian torsion
Mature teratoma
Tubo-ovarian abscess
Ovarian endometrioma

questions.text: The following pelvic sonogram image signifies which of the following conditions? '
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Ovarian endometrioma

  • This ultrasound image is of an endometrioma
  • It shows fine stippling (ground glass appearance) which is characteristic of an endometrioma which is basically a collection of old blood (Chocolate cyst)

Other Options: 

  • Option A: OVarian torsion: This is diagnosed on Doppler and not only on plain USG
  • Option B: Mature teratoma: This will give the following appearance on ultraosund:
    • Tip of iceberg sign: An echogenic interface at the edge of the mass that obscures the deep structures
    • Rokitansky nodule
    • Echogenic bony structures like teeth
    • Fluid levels
    • Acoustic shadowing
    • Dot-dash pattern (due to hair)

  • Option C: Tubo ovarian abscess on ultrasound will appear as:
    • Multilocular complex adnexal mass with debris, septations and rreguar thick walls

Educational Objective: 

  • This is how an endometriotic ovarian cyst looks like on ultrasound
  • Treatment: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy

Ref: Page 216, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Hydrosalpinx
Hemoperitoneum
Corpus luteum cyst
Abdominal pregnancy

questions.text: Your patient presents with acute lower abdominal pain, 8 weeks of amenorrhea, and vaginal spotting. She has a history of gonorrhea, and her pregnancy test result is positive. A transvaginal sonographic sagittal view of her uterus and cul-de-sac is shown here. These findings are most suggestive of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hemoperitoneum

  • This is a scenario of an ectopic pregnancy (features of PID given are a clue as ectopic pregnancy is seen in women with salpingitis)
  • The image shows hemoperitoneum (note the black fluid behind the uterus)
  • Hence this is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy (classic triad of symptoms + hemoperitoneum on the ultrasound)

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Hydrosalpinx: In this there will not be a h/o amenorrhoea or UPT +ve. There will be pain/ fever/ vaginal discharge. The USG will show a retort shaped structure as shown: 

  • Option C: Corpus Luteal Cyst: This is commonly seen in pregnancy. There uually wont be associated spotting or abdominal pain and it will appear as a simple ovarian cyst as shown: 

 

  • Option D: Abdominal pregnancy: It is very difficult to diagnose on ultrasound but the uterus will be empty (No gestational sac or fetus seen insde the uterus)

Educational Objective:

USG features of ectopic pregnancy

1. Ruptured: Hemoperitoneum with an adnexal mass

2. Unruptured: 

  • A gestational sac with yolk sac and/or fetal pole seen in the adnexal region
  • Bagel sign
  • Blob sign
  • Ring f fire sign (On doppler)
  • Pseudo sac intra-uterine

Ref: Page 218, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Antral follicles
Primary follicles
Apoptotic follicles
Preantral follicles

questions.text: A 29-year-old female with irregular cycles presents for evaluation. A sonogram of her ovaries reveals the following findings. The ovarian follicles seen are which type
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Antral follicles

  • This is an ovary showing Polycystic morphology
  • Sonographic criteria or polycystic ovaries from the 2003 Rotterdam conference include ≥ 12 small antral follicles (2 to 9 mm in diameter) or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both
  • Only one ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS

Educational Objective: 

  • Sonographic criteria or polycystic ovaries from the 2003 Rotterdam conference include ≥ 12 small antral follicles (2 to 9 mm in diameter) or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both
  • Only one ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS

Ref: Page 397, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Normal
Uterine didelphys
Bilateral hydrosalpinges
Unilateral proximal tubal blockage

questions.text: What is your interpretation of the following hysterosalpingogram (HSG)?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Bilateral hydrosalpinges

  • This is an HSG image showing a normal uterine cavity
  • The tubes are well delineated, but the dye is seen to accumulate in both the tubes without any spill seen
  • This is characteristic of hydrosalpinx

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Normal: This is not a normal HSG. In a normal HSG, free b/l spill should be seen as like this: 

  • Option B: Uterine didelphys: This appears on an HSG as 2 completely seperate uterine cavities with no connection like this: 

  • Option C: Unilateral proximal tubal blockage: This appears as shown below: 

Educational Objective: 

This is a normal HSG: 

Ref: Page 440, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition
